thread.section_title: Australian Business & World Finance News - Yahoo!7 Finance
thread.title: $A lower after weak economic data

title: $A lower after weak economic data
text:
Mon, Aug 31, 2015, 6:36 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A lower after weak economic data AAP – 51 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has been weighed down by a looming interest rate hike in the US and concerns about the local economy. 
At 1700 AEST on Monday, the local unit was trading at 71.42 US cents, down from 71.67 cents on Friday. 
Money markets struggled to make much ground, not helped by the Australian and Chinese share markets falling one per cent or more, HC Securities senior private client adviser Mark Lennox said. 
"The major factors remain the timing of a potential US Fed rate increase and the high probability of a hard landing within the Chinese economy," he said. 
Over the weekend, US central bankers urged the Federal Reserve to raise their interest rate in September. 
IG chief market strategist Chris Weston said the Australian dollar was also impacted by disappointing business data, and anticipation of the Reserve Bank of Australia's board meeting on Tuesday. 
Estimated business inventories were flat in the June quarter, after a strong rise in the previous quarter. 
"The Australian dollar is getting a lot of focus, partly due to tomorrow's Reserve Bank meeting and partly because today's second quarter inventory data suggests downside risks to Wednesday second quarter GDP print," he said. 
The RBA is expected to keep the cash rate unchanged at two per cent, but the focus will be on its thoughts about the recent market turmoil sparked by big falls on the Chinese stock market. 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 86.54 Japanese yen, down from Friday's close of 86.75 yen, and at 63.62 euro cents, up from 63.61 euro cents. 
Meanwhile, the local bond market was firmer. 
"That reflects weakness in Chinese equity markets and downward revisions to Wednesday's GDP (gross domestic product) figures," Nomura rates strategist Andrew Ticehurst said. 
At 1630 AEST, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.305 (implying a yield of 2.695 per cent), up from 97.235 (2.765 per cent) on Friday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.230 (1.870 per cent), up from 98.170 (1.830 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Home price rises slowed in August AAP
